simulated_ratings.title: Amelie (Fabuleux destin d'Amélie Poulain, Le) (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Whimsical, kind-hearted romance that charmed me even if the whimsy sometimes felt a bit precious.

simulated_ratings.title: David Attenborough: A Life on Our Planet (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sobering yet hopeful reflection on our world that resonated with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Gandhi (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A stirring portrait of moral courage that felt both intimate and epic.

simulated_ratings.title: Patch of Blue, A (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender and humane, it moved me deeply with its quiet dignity.

simulated_ratings.title: Koyaanisqatsi (a.k.a. Koyaanisqatsi: Life Out of Balance) (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visually striking and thought-provoking, but the lack of narrative kept me at a distance.

simulated_ratings.title: Guess Who's Coming to Dinner (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Well-meaning and engaging, its emotional core still lands.

simulated_ratings.title: Wallace & Gromit in The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, warm British whimsy that kept me smiling.

simulated_ratings.title: Wallace & Gromit: The Best of Aardman Animation (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A delightful showcase of wit and craft with consistent charm.

simulated_ratings.title: Saraband (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Intense and intimate, I admired its honesty even when it bruised.

simulated_ratings.title: Laurence Anyways (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Compassionate and bold, its emotional honesty won me over.

simulated_ratings.title: Alone in the Wilderness (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A quietly captivating testament to resilience and craft in nature.

simulated_ratings.title: Heima (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeous and atmospheric, more mood than story but affecting.

simulated_ratings.title: Wallace & Gromit: The Wrong Trousers (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive, perfectly paced, and hilarious—top-tier Aardman.

simulated_ratings.title: Chariots of Fire (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Thoughtful and stirring, if a bit reserved, with themes that linger.

simulated_ratings.title: Dead Poets Society (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A rousing ode to inspiration that spoke straight to my heart.

simulated_ratings.title: Wallace & Gromit's Cracking Contraptions (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Light, clever vignettes—fun, if slight.

simulated_ratings.title: Story of the Weeping Camel, The (Geschichte vom weinenden Kamel, Die) (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, humane portrait of family and tradition that moved me.

simulated_ratings.title: Street Fight (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A riveting, clear-eyed look at grassroots politics that kept me engaged.

simulated_ratings.title: Mission, The (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Powerful and morally complex, with haunting beauty.

simulated_ratings.title: Harvie Krumpet (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quirky and warm, with a bittersweet human core.

simulated_ratings.title: Autumn Sonata (Höstsonaten) (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A piercing mother-daughter reckoning, finely acted and emotionally raw.

simulated_ratings.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A meditative portrait of art and impermanence that intrigued me.

simulated_ratings.title: Why We Fight (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharp, thoughtful, and urgent in its critique of militarism.

simulated_ratings.title: Secret Life of Words, The (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A quiet, intimate healing story that rewarded my patience.

simulated_ratings.title: Awakenings (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deeply humane and uplifting without losing its poignancy.

simulated_ratings.title: March of the Penguins (Marche de l'empereur, La) (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An elegant, heartfelt nature chronicle with striking imagery.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Stylish gloom with a hollow core that kept me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Acerbic anti-war absurdity I admired more than I enjoyed.

simulated_ratings.title: Addicted to Love (1997)

simulated_ratings.title: Gifted Hands: The Ben Carson Story (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inspiring and straightforward, it moved me despite its conventional sheen.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Rich, humane, and deeply felt—tradition versus change hit home.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever concept with some wit, though the satire doesn’t always land.

simulated_ratings.title: Transcendence (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Big ideas, muted emotions

simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm-hearted culture clash with messy humanity that mostly works.

simulated_ratings.title: Born Yesterday (1950)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Witty, pointed, and charmingly romantic.

simulated_ratings.title: Mr. & Mrs. Smith (1941)

simulated_ratings.title: October Baby (2011)

simulated_ratings.title: Singh is Bling (2015)

simulated_ratings.title: P.S. I Love You (2007)

simulated_ratings.title: Bang the Drum Slowly (1973)
